key_channel_insights.line_content: While OTA maintains over 93% price parity, it is experiencing a 2.3 point weekly erosion, offset by deeper discounts on far-out bookings and growing premiums on non-US origins.
MSE undercuts website fares on 95.7% of routes, with minimal premiums (0.06% of itineraries) and slight parity growth (2.22%), marking it as the most discount-oriented channel.
GDS holds parity on 89.05% of itineraries but saw a 2.03-point weekly decline, alongside rising undercutting to 2.62% and pronounced misalignment in far-out bookings.

conclusion.line_content: This report provides a high-level summary of the price discrepancies observed across different channels.  It is important to note that the data contains many nuances depending on various factors such as market conditions, booking windows, and the competitive landscape. Understanding these subtleties can be critical in optimizing pricing strategies and ensuring competitive positioning.

As part of our 'PriceEye' solution, we are developing an intuitive dashboard designed to help your airline's analysts drill down into this data. This tool will allow you to uncover and focus on critical actionable insights, enabling your team to make data-driven decisions with confidence.

We are here to support you in leveraging these insights to enhance your revenue management and distribution strategies. Please don't hesitate to connect with our team for more information about how PriceEye can assist you in achieving your business objectives.

ota_highlights.line_content: Price parity remains dominant on OTA at 93.5% of itineraries last week, but parity has eased by 2.3 percentage points from the prior week.
Routes originating outside the US show 28.3% of offers priced higher on OTA—more than a quarter of itineraries, up 2.2 points week-on-week.

ota_highlights.line_title: Far-Out Bookings Yield More OTA Discounts
ota_highlights.line_content: Tickets booked far in advance see 5.6% lower prices on OTA, a 4.7 point increase from the previous week, indicating deeper discounts in early sales.

ota_summary_high_level_comparison.line_content: OTA parity is above 93% but is down 2.3 points week-on-week and 1.8 points month-on-month.
OTA offers are lower in 2.60% of cases, up 2.04 points week-on-week and 1.62 points month-on-month, with average discounts around 1%.
Higher OTA prices occur in 1.01% of itineraries, down 0.34 points week-on-week, with an average premium of 0.09%.
OTA availability gaps cover 2.88% of routes, rising 0.59 points from last week and 0.23 points month-on-month.

ota_summary_by_region.line_content: Short-haul parity stands at 93.4% with 2.68% of itineraries discounted on OTA (up 2.10 points) and 1.04% priced higher.
Long-haul routes maintain 97.9% parity, with no lower- or higher-priced OTA offers recorded last week.

ota_summary_by_point_of_origin.line_content: US departures exhibit 94.4% parity, 0.6% of itineraries priced higher on OTA, and 2.65% lower-priced OTA discounts (up 2.11 points).
Non-US departures have 68.8% parity while 28.3% of fares are higher on OTA, a 2.2 point weekly increase.

ota_summary_by_booking_window.line_content: Close-in bookings show 94.2% parity, with 0.89% higher-OTA offers and 1.26% lower-OTA discounts.
Far-out bookings record 91.97% parity, 1.29% higher OTA prices and elevated 5.63% OTA discounts (up 4.74 points).

mse_highlights.line_content: In the latest week, 95.7% of routes on MSE displayed fares below the website, reflecting a slight 0.23% week-on-week decrease but a 1.25% month-on-month increase.
Only 0.06% of itineraries had higher MSE fares last week, carrying an average 7% premium over the website.
2.22% of routes matched website prices in the latest week, up 0.18% from the prior week, indicating slight parity expansion.

mse_summary_high_level_comparison.line_content: 2.06% of ODs lacked an MSE listing last week, roughly flat week-on-week and down 0.67% versus the prior month.
Price parity occurred on 2.22% of ODs last week, a 0.18% increase week-on-week but a 0.59% decrease month-on-month.
MSE overpricing affected 0.06% of routes last week, 0.04% more than the prior week, with an average +7% price uplift.
MSE undercut website fares on 95.7% of routes last week, a slight 0.23% dip week-on-week yet a 1.25% climb month-on-month, with an average 0.17% discount.

mse_summary_by_region.line_content: On short-haul routes, 95.7% of ODs saw MSE undercut pricing last week, slightly lower week-on-week but up 1.18% month-on-month, with parity at 2.14%.
On long-haul routes, 93.1% of listings were discounted last week, up 2.85% week-on-week and 3.62% month-on-month, narrowing the average discount to 0.09%.

mse_summary_by_point_of_origin.line_content: US-origin itineraries saw MSE fares lower on 96.6% of routes, a marginal 0.14% decline week-on-week but a 1.26% rise month-on-month.
For non-US origins, price parity spiked to 29.5% last week (+2.62% week-on-week), limiting discounts to 68.8% of routes.

mse_summary_by_booking_window.line_content: Within close-in bookings, 95.7% of itineraries were discounted on MSE last week, sustaining a 0.18% average discount and minimal parity at 1.8%.
In far-out windows, parity reached 3.23% (+0.43% week-on-week) with discounts covering 95.6% of itineraries, indicating more price alignment for advance purchases.

gds_highlights.line_content: Alaska’s GDS channel maintained price parity on 89.05% of routes last week, though this represents a 2.03-point weekly decline in alignment with the website.
Instances where GDS fares undershot the website quadrupled to 2.62% of itineraries—up 2.06 points week-over-week—even as the average discount remained modest at 0.02%.
Bookings made far in advance saw parity drop 5.10 points to 87.13% and undercutting climb 4.61 points to 5.56%, signaling misalignment in longer booking windows.

gds_summary_high_level_comparison.line_content: 7.02% of all ODs lacked a website offer in GDS last week, nearly unchanged from 6.99% the prior week.
89.05% of routes saw identical fares on GDS versus the website, a 2.03-point weekly decrease and 0.16-point monthly dip.
1.31% of itineraries carried higher GDS fares, stable week-over-week, with an average 0.11% markup versus the website.
2.62% of itineraries featured lower GDS fares—up 2.06 points week-over-week—with an average 0.02% discount.

gds_summary_by_region.line_content: Short-haul routes saw parity at 88.87% (down 2.16 points), with GDS undercutting rising to 2.68% (up 2.12 points) and an unchanged average discount of 0.02%.
Long-haul itineraries held 95.83% parity (up 2.17 points), with no recorded undercutting or premiums—though the two-route sample is limited.

gds_summary_by_point_of_origin.line_content: US-origin routes showed 90.08% parity (down 2.18 points), a 2.67% share of GDS undercuts (up 2.13 points) at a 0.02% average discount.
Non-US itineraries had only 59.54% parity (up 0.68 points) with GDS premiums dominant at 30.06% (down 3.09 points) and a 0.07% average markup.

gds_summary_by_booking_window.line_content: Close-in fares held 89.93% parity (down 0.67 points), with undercuts rising to 1.32% (up 0.94 points) at a 0.03% average discount.
Far-out bookings dropped to 87.13% parity (down 5.10 points) while undercuts surged to 5.56% (up 4.61 points) at a 0.01% average discount.
